moves.1. c4 c5 2. e4 Qa5 3. Nc3 g6 4. a4: I kind of like Pd3 better.
moves.4... Qb4: Ok, Nd5 looks really good.  Classic king/rook fork.
moves.5. Nf3 Bh6 6. d3: I still like Nd5 better.  Can't now.
moves.6... Bg7 7. Bg5: What does black want to do?  BxN.  PxB.  QxP+.  White keeps the rook but is down a pawn and cannot castle.
moves.8. Nb5: QxR, QxQ, BxQ, Nc7+, white gets the rook back.  Black defends against the white fork first with Na6.
moves.8... Na6 9. Rb1 Qa2 10. Be2 d6 11. O-O N: Ok, white should fork the rook.  Nc7+
moves.13. Rb1: But so does white.  Nc7+ is still good.
moves.13... Qa2 14. Ra1: White offers black the rook again.
moves.17. Qe1: Why?  Black can still nab the rook, though maybe still does not see it.
moves.18. Rb1 Nc2 19. Qd2 Qa2 20. Nh4: Nc7+, for the sake of Pete!
moves.20... f6 21. Bf4: Nope.  Pg5 pawn forks the bishop and knight.  Nf5 does not help because BxN, PxB, PxBf4, QxP.
moves.21... a6: Ok, black wants to force white to take the rook.  Nice.
moves.22... Qa3 23. Qxc2: Well, the rook was worth more.
moves.23... b5 24. axb5 axb5 25. cxb5: NxP is better.  Even RxP keeps white's pawns from being split, but NxP repositions the night for forking that rook.
moves.25... Rb8: Black also still has that pawn fork, Pg5.
moves.29... Qa3: White is up a knight, but ought to move either the knight or bishop on the 4 rank.  Maybe Bg3.
moves.37... Bd7: Time to push the pawn, maybe.
moves.38. Ba5: Nothing protecting that bishop.  Qa2 might have been better.
Rook and bishop for rook.  Not so good.
moves.46... Rxb7 47. h3 Be6: Uh, the rook is worth more.  Should have moved it instead.
moves.48. Rb1: Black is ahead nine points.  Every trade now favors black.
moves.48... Ra7: Black should have taken the rook.
moves.49. Rb7: This did not work last time.  White loses another rook.
moves.49... Rxb7 50. Bxb7 Qxb7 51. Qa3 Qb1+ 52: Be7 would help get that rook out.
moves.56... h6 57. hxg5: Worse idea.  Now the rook is open.
Pf3 saves the knight, temporarily.  This is force mate.  RxN+, Kg1, Qd1#.
